description: Unknown; apparently related to Scots and dialect pirl (“twist, ripple, whirl, spin”), and possibly to Older Scots pyrl ("thrust or poke at"). Compare Venetian pirlo, an embellishment where the woven threads are twisted together. May be unrelated to purfle, though the meanings are similar.

entries.meaning: A particular stitch in knitting; an inversion of stitches giving the work a ribbed or waved appearance.
The edge of lace trimmed with loops.
An embroidered and puckered border; a hem or fringe, often of gold or silver twist; also, a pleat or fold, as of a band.

verbs.description: purl (third-person singular simple present purls, present participle purling, simple past and past participle purled)

entries.meaning: To decorate with fringe or embroidered edge
(knitting) To use an inverted stitch producing ribbing etc.

description: from Middle English pirle (“whirligig”), Middle Italian pirla (“whipping top”).

entries.meaning: a heavy or headlong fall; an upset.

verbs.description: purl (third-person singular simple present purls, present participle purling, simple past and past participle purled)

entries.meaning: (archaic) To upset, to spin, capsize, fall heavily, fall headlong.
examples: The huntsman was purled from his horse.

description: From Old Norse purla (“to babble”), possibly ultimately from an imitative Germanic base related to Dutch polder, Norwegian puldra (“to gush”) and pulla (“to bubble”), Old English polr (“marsh”).

entries.meaning: A circle made by the motion of a fluid; an eddy; a ripple.
examples: Whose streame an easie breath doth seeme to blowe; Which on the sparkling grauell runns in purles, / As though the waues had been of siluer curles

entries.meaning: A gentle murmuring sound, such as that produced by the running of a liquid among obstructions.

verbs.description: purl (third-person singular simple present purls, present participle purling, simple past and past participle purled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To flow with a murmuring sound in swirls and eddies.
To rise in circles, ripples, or undulations; to curl; to mantle.

description: Possibly from the pearl-like appearance caused by bubbles on the surface of the liquid.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Ale or beer spiced with wormwood or other bitter herbs, regarded as a tonic.
(archaic) Hot beer mixed with gin, sugar, and spices.
examples: Drank a glass of purl to recover appetite.
